awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Employees' Response to OPM Data Breaches: Decision Making in the Context of Anxiety and Fatigue
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description
According to recent reports in the press, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) was hit hard in two recent cyber-attacks (OPM 2015). In April 2015, OPM discovered that personal data (e.g., Social Security Numbers, full name, and birth date) of 4.2 million current and former Federal government employees had been stolen (referred to as personnel records incident hereafter). Later in June 2015, OPM discovered that around 21.5 million employees - current and former Federal employees and contractors - were affected as their personal information such as Social Security Numbers, fingerprints, and background investigation records were compromised (referred to as background investigation records incident hereafter). Unlike other information, sensitive data such as the background investigation records, which include personal histories, relationships, and biometrics, reveal employees' personal lives are difficult to be re-issued. Typical protection such as a few months of credit monitoring may be insufficient in protecting victims from determined attackers.  To date, little is known about how and why people decide and act in the aftermath of breaches involving their personal data. In particular, the role of data breach fatigue, manifested by insensitivity to data breaches and low estimate of fraud loss, in affecting people's decisions and actions is unknown. The existing research has also been silent on employees' decision making and reactions in response to data breaches. To fill this research gap, in this proposal, we plan to conduct a study that reveals the key decision factors, response actions, and the potential effect of data breach fatigue in the context of anxiety over the possible outcomes of the breach. Findings of the study will help in understanding employee reactions towards data breaches. New knowledge will help industry and policy makers develop intervention strategies that avert the effect of breach fatigue

Technical Description
This proposal will explore the crucial issues that influence employees' responses in the context of the recent two OPM data breach incidents. This proposed research will compare these two different incidents and their impacts on different types of victims, employees who receive notification of the personnel records incident (now), employees who receive notification of both incidents (future), and employees who only receive notification of the background investigation records incident (future). We will also survey employees who have not received any notification, as a control group. In addition to self-reported data through surveys, we shall extend this study by capturing organic Twitter messages related to the two breach incidents in the respective time periods in 2015 to study how people coped with breach incidents. Utilizing natural language processing, we intend to (1) explore patterns of discourses associated with the data breach fatigue, (2) extract coping mechanisms from the discourses, and (3) compare coping mechanisms of employees, identified from the survey and those derived from the data mining.

Title: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Employees' Response to OPM Data Breaches: Decision Making in the Context of Anxiety and Fatigue

This project examined how and why citizens react to data breach incidents. In addition, this project explored the role of data breach fatigue in affecting individuals’ post-breach decisions and actions.

The investigators executed the project using the 2015 Office of Personnel Management (OPM) data breach as the main research context. They surveyed both victims and non-victims of the 2015 OPM breach and used statistical approaches to validate a series of conceptual models that might explain individuals’ decision making and actions in response to data breach news. The results revealed the underlying mechanisms which explain the individual differences in their data breach reactions. A number of factors were found to account for post-breach actions, which range from mal-adaptive to adaptive ones.

By comparing both victims and non-victims, it was found that the victimization experience of data breaches affected one’s critical perceptions as well as post-breach actions. Compared to non-victims, data breach victims perceived a greater level of threat from future identity thefts, which might follow the OPM breach, and they actually engaged more heavily in taking protective actions. Regarding online users’ post-breach actions, it was found that the drivers for the actions were different between victims and non-victims. Among others, non-victims’ actions were driven by their use of emotion-focused coping strategies (i.e., regulating one’s stress emotion) as well as problem-focused coping strategies (i.e., fighting the problem head-on). In contrast, victims’ reactions were driven by problem-focused coping strategies only. The antecedents to the use of coping strategies also diffed between the two groups.

Data breach fatigue was found to be higher among non-victims than victims. This cognitive bias was found to impact several important perceptions, which shaped one’s coping and protective actions against future identity theft. The effect of data breach fatigue was destructive as it oftentimes lead online users to underestimate the threat of identity theft, reduce their use of problem-focused coping, promote the use of emotion-focused coping, and decrease protective actions. Moreover, data breach fatigue might also alter online users’ emotion after learning breach incidents and subsequently affect their perceptions of breach impact. 

Furthermore, the investigators gathered survey data from citizens regarding the 2016 Yahoo data breaches: victims of the September 2016 Yahoo breach, victims of the December 2016 Yahoo breach, victims of both breaches, and non-victims. This additional dataset was used to compare individuals' reactions to the OPM breach and the Yahoo breach.

Finally, the investigators retrieved Twitter data on users' response to OPM breach. The dataset was analyzed to develop an understanding of how the public reacted to breach events. It was revealed that the public displayed a unique pattern of emotional response (e.g., anxiety, anger, and sadness) to breach news. This pattern differed from what existing theories (e.g., Kübler-Ross model) would have predicted.
